comment._content: I was always fascinated by these and wondered how they could tell them apart?  Imagine the chaos if he had a few jars on when operating these???

comment._content: When my father was young, he did the same work.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I was just kidding about the drink though you can be sure it happened, if caught instant dismissal!  These guys were so used to things and had plates on the critical ones to tell them what was what and where they went.  I remember wathcing some of them in action and they looking like conductors of orchestra's they were so good at their work.

comment._content: I've got a photo of my great uncle David in the same environment and in the exact same position when he worked for British Rail in Dumfrieshire!

comment._content: Nice Photo & Place. Nice looking Young Man. The lives of many people must have been in his hands as he guided the Moving Trains - - -

comment.author: 9881845@N03
comment._content: I believe the name of the Signalman in this photo to me Mattie Darcy who lived in the Railway Cottages just across the road (on the Galway Road)  from the back of the signal cabin.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/9881845@N03] I'm so sorry that I missed your comment! Thanks a million for letting us know! We have other Athlone West photos that mention an M. Darcy, so if it's the same gentleman, I'll change the catalogue record for those ones too. Do you know if Mattie Darcy is still alive?
